question.text: The ray PQ shown in the figure, suffers minimum deviation in an equilateral prism A. Two more identical prism B and C and of the same material as A are now placed in contact as shown in the figure. If prism A produces a minimum deviation δm, the deviation produced by the combination of prisms A, B and C will be

solution.text: The ray <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>PQ</mi></math> will undergo minimum deviation in prism <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> if the angle of the incident on <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is such that the refracted ray in <math><mi>A</mi></math> is parallel to its base. Since prisms <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> are identical to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and are made of the same materials as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, the refracted ray in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> suffers no further deviation by prisms <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Hence the emergent ray from prism <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> will suffer the same deviation as that produced by prism <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>. Hence the correct choice is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math>.
